file_content.text: Here in this cave, we founders discussed our vision for the Jedi Order. And I, Rajivari, listened.
I listened, as they carefully crippled our newborn order. As they argued for mediocrity. It shall not stand.
I have laid my plans. With my army made from Tython's true dark sons, I will purge this council of fools while they chatter.
Wait, what does he mean by "Tython's true dark sons"?
"Dark sons"?
Attention, small hunter. Is more.
Rajivari planned to assassinate the fledgling Jedi Council with some sort of army.
This was his betrayal.
Even with an army, one man challenging the first Jedi Council was no mean feat.
That was very daring.
Only my apprentices and I will survive. From Kaleth, we will mold the Jedi into what we deserve to be.
If the hilt of the first blade has been returned, we succeeded, and the future follows the path we left.
Follow, seeker. Follow the path to the Fount of Rajivari. It is time.
Is strange map. Have never seen like. If path is there, I cannot see.
I can make out some of it, but the rest is gibberish.
I understand a little....
Let's take this back to the Jedi Temple. Master Yuon can help us interpret it.
Master Yuon should see this.
He could have just told us where the Fount of Rajivari is, and saved time.
It's maddeningly unclear.
Is old thing. Yuon knows of these, should bring back to her.
I go ahead; shall meet you in Yuon's rooms, small hunter.
And here. First blade's hilt, do not forget. Would hate you to suffer Yuon's wrath.
Flesh Raiders are dead? Hmm. Strong, healthy--worth many Jagganath points.
But, hunted many Flesh Raiders coming here. So, shall allow you these points, small hunter. This time.
I see is no understanding. I will tell.
For us, hunt is life. To make honorable kills, earn Jagganath points. All tallied by Scorekeeper.
Scorekeeper. She sees all. Greater score, more points--is greater standing in Scorekeeper's eyes. Greater glory.
Yes. Is not many Jedi who understand.
Many. Score is no meaning to outsiders.
Cannot see "Force" Yuon talks of. Cannot smell, or eat. But is real. Is so with Scorekeeper.
Enough talk; have Fount of Rajivari to find. This carving. Is any signs?
If you say. But--hmm.
Smell something... strange. Bones, there. All old. And all in pile. Is deliberate, but... not Flesh Raider way.
If you say. But have seen nowhere else.
Go soft, small hunter. Smell Flesh Raider... and smell not-Flesh Raider, too.
Was scent, so I spoke. But do as pleases you.
[These bones are brittle, and badly gnawed. Moving them aside, you see the bones were piled over an ancient pedestal.]
[Examining it reveals the pedestal has an alcove, exactly the size and shape of the hilt you found in Kaleth.]
Thanks for coming so fast, Jedi. That Flesh Raider stench was making us dizzy.
There's Flesh Raiders all over these caves. Didn't they see you?
How did you get in here?
Nalen cut a path for us. Hid his scent, then took those things down in a flash.
I think we've met before.
You were in Kalikori village.
I remember. You talked to us like we were nothing.
Yes, we have. Please don't make this hard.
I was hoping to see Nalen again. We have things to discuss.
Is Nalen Raloch with you?
Nalen said to wait for you. You've got something he needs. He has to find this "Fount of Rajivari," to keep defending our village.
I'm sorry--you were straight with us. But I have to take whatever "first blade" you found in Kaleth. Nalen needs it.
I won't give you anything that might help Nalen.
I'm keeping it. [Attack]
I don't want to do this. But if it comes down to you, or my village... I'm sorry.
You promised the Jedi would help us but nothing's changed. So we need whatever "first blade" you got in Kaleth.
We've seen what Jedi are like. When someone contradicts you, out come the lightsabers. I want whatever "first blade" you found in Kaleth. Now.
Nalen only cares about the Fount of Rajivari. Sending you here risked your lives when he supposedly wants to save you.
Listen. Nalen is insane.
You don't get it. We're all... we're scared.
Nalen hardly comes into the village now. Barely eats, or sleeps. And when you talk to him, his eyes are so strange.
I can't give Nalen what he wants. But stand down, and I'll do what I can for him.
Let me help him.
I should speak to Nalen myself. Where can I find him?
Do you know where he is?
No one knows. He mentioned exploring Kaleth, but that was hours ago, he'll be long gone.
Take the others back to the village where you belong. Leave Nalen to me.
Just leave.
Something terrible's happening, isn't it? Keep your artifact, whatever it is. Keep it away from Nalen.
Jedi. Please, don't hurt him. Whatever Nalen's become, he did this for us.
I can't give you what I found. But as an apology, let me make a donation to Kalikori village's funds.
I can offer credits instead.
That's right--you took that holoprojector back, didn't you? That could have bought us a lot of medicine.
Here. This should compensate you.
I thought you were a thug in a Jedi robe. But this... it's fair barter.
Nalen's been saying a lot of things about the Jedi. But maybe he didn't have everything straight.
We should... get these back to the village. That blade will have to wait. Thanks, Jedi. I guess you're alright.
I'm not giving you the hilt of the first blade, or anything else of mine.
Forget it. [Attack]
Then I guess we'll have to take it.
Small hunter, should not fight these. Are only soft things, no honor or points in killing. Will not raise hand against them.
Sorry, Jedi. Search the body when it's done!
Sorry, I don't understand what you mean by "Jagganath points."
What "points"?
That's very... gracious of you.
Thank you. I think.
Whatever "points" you're talking about are mine.
I earn my own victories.
So hunting is how you serve your goddess, this "Scorekeeper," and increase your status.
I see. You hunt for prestige.
How many of these Jagganath points do you have?
What is your score, then?
Killing animals to impress some invisible scorekeeper seems... odd.
What a strange religion.
It's badly eroded. I can't see anything that might help us.
Nothing I can decipher.
Apparently not. Do you have any ideas?
I could use your help.
I won't know unless I have time to study it.
Don't rush me.
I should examine them. Maybe piling up the oldest bones is somehow significant to the Flesh Raiders.
It could be ritual behavior.
It's a place to begin, at least.
I'll take a look.
Why does it matter what Flesh Raiders do? We're looking for clues about Rajivari, or this hilt.
I don't care about bones.
